summary: Dead to Rights: Retribution Deserved More Recognition
reviewText: Developed by Volatile, a branch of Blitz Games Studios, infamously known for the 3 Burger King games, Dead to Rights: Retribution was a game I didn't expect much out of. Maybe perhaps the best game to compare it to was another another gem made by Volatile, Reservoir Dogs, back in 2006. While this game isn't flawless, it's still a game that I got complete satisfaction out of. Dead to Rights: Retribution is the perfect bargain bin game. Not only is it way better than typical bargain bin fodder, but it's a legitimately good game that happened to get little to no recognition upon its initial release. Forget about the previous Dead to Rights games, which were pretty much lacking in every area. Dead to Rights: Retribution has redeemed this franchise.Gameplay revolves around third-person shooting using cover, in addition to a lot of hand-to-hand melee similar to that of Arkham Asylum/City and Sleeping Dogs. While its not as refined or smooth as those titles, it's still really well done and a lot of fun, adding some variety to what would otherwise be a fun but standard third-person shooter.As far as story goes, I really enjoyed it and thought they did a good job telling it. The ending is particular exciting and climactic. This is a very cinematic game.I thought the graphics and rain effects were beautiful in this game. While you'll notice a few odd looking character models and some rough edges throughout, it's an otherwise nice looking game overall.Dead to Rights: Retribution is a game that fits in the "hidden gem" category perfectly. Great game.

summary: 3.5 star... a mixed bag of new found success and the persistent lost of the old legacies
reviewText: FF XIII is by no means a bad game. However, it's not exactly an heir to the throne either. New good stuff were added, but the old legacies which helped FF series gripped the heart of their fans were still lost.Here we go...PROS:- Battle System is fun. It starts off slow and seems boring, even a bit clunky, at first. But you'll get more and more comfortable with the system as you proceed. It also gets deeper as you start facing tougher enemies.  You can't win the fight without strategic thinking and being quick on the execution. Many fights seem impossible, until you grasp the right strategy.Many complains about not being able to control all the team members. That doesn't bother me much since the AI is quite reliable, and the Active Time Battle in this one is quite a bit too rushing to put in commands for everyone anyway. Paradigm system works as effectively as the Gambit system in FF XII, and it's simpler to set up.- Item and skill upgrading systems are similar to that of FF X. They're not revolutionary, but not at all bad.- Art direction and graphics are, of course, impressive as ever. Soundtracks, though not imressive and not much of a romance in the melodies, get the job done.CONS:- The game forces you to endure an endless limbo of boredom during the first long hours, and that's critical. The game makes you switching back and forth between all the two-man teams of the 6 characters who got separated. I understand that it's a form of story telling. But 20-30 hours of very limited strategies and fighting hordes after hordes of weaklings seems like eternity. It picks up the pace greatly after the reunion of all characters. But for those with low tolerance, the first hours is more than enough to make them throw away the game.- Being unable to control other team members or removing of the MP system might get on your nerve at first, though not a big deal and you'll get over it eventually. But what really frustrated me is that the death of the team leader alone decides the fate of the whole team. It means, in the tough fights, your only option for the team leader is the characters with high strength, not the mages. And since tough fights do come along quite often later in the game, you'll find yourself using the same set of characters over and over. Trying new combinations might spoil the fun rather than improving it.- Story telling is less than impressive. It's not exactly sucky, but definitely not good. Character development hardly occurs. Though it's not as bad as FF XII, but you don't really care about the characters either.Now the unforgiveable part. The developers did quite a good job creating an interesting world. BUT, sadly, they took the lazy way out of a story telling hassle by putting them in the glossary and notes. I'm talking about the descriptions of the locales, background stories, and even many crucial points of the main story line that would help players to understand. It wouldn't be a big deal if this was a PS1 game, but it's not.Story telling and soundtrack of FF series have gone down the dangerous path since Hironobu Sakaguchi and Nobuo Uematsu left Square-Enix after FF X. The developers that took over the projects had done terrible jobs so far. And I'm certain that it's a fatal blow to the heart of FF fans....We dropped the controller when Aerith was stabbed in FF VII, from that moment on, revenge on Sephiroth was personal......We smiled with the two-generation romances of Rinoa and Squall and his father and her mother in FF VIII......We shed the tears with Yuna when Tidus faded away in FF X, and were happy to see their reunion in FF X-2 (even though FF X-2's gameplay sucked)All other FFs also had their moments of emotional grip. And those moments are what set FF apart from other JRPGs.But since FF XII, they focused too much on the gameplay. You could still go on for a 100 hours on quests and leveling up. I don't say that it's a bad thing to be creative on the gameplay. But those moments are no more. The stories and characters in FF XII and XIII are... bland. And spending 50-80 hours taking in a story of the boring or annoying characters is not a happy time for FF fans.If SE's teams won't develop their story telling skill to be at least on par with the old members who left for Mistwalker, this franchise might someday die a tragic death or transform into something entirely different, and lesser.- Dialogues in FF XIII are cheesy. Voice acting of Vanille is unbearable.IN CONCLUSION:3.5 stars from me. (I can't believe I give an FF less than 4 stars. Sad but true)FF XIII feels a lot similar to FF X. Better in the esthetic department (of course, it's a generation apart), different and fresh in the gameplay department, but a lot lesser in the story department.  The game itself is not a bad RPG, but considering all the series' landmarks that are lost, it's not a good FF.Die-hard fans, like me, might find it to be reasonably fun and a bit dissapointing at the same time. I got my money's worth nonetheless.But if I want my friends to love FF, I won't recommend this one as their first game in the series. At least not until the price dropped.

summary: A sleek, sexy handheld with loads of potential
reviewText: Despite the fact that it’s been touted as a major commercial failure in recent months (primarily in comparison to its sole competitor, the Nintendo 3DS), my interest was sparked in the PlayStation Vita thanks to a little game called Gravity Rush, and it was enough to motivate me to dash out and purchase the commercially floundering handheld. I’m happy to say I’m thus far satisfied with the purchase; the Vita is above all else a seriously sexy system, with fantastic features and loads of potential. Although its current catalogue of software leaves much to be desired and there are a handful of frustrating drawbacks, this console offers great fun for the hardcore gamer on the go.The Vita is an impressively powerful system for a handheld, boasting a gorgeous 960x544 OLED multi-touch screen display; at a nicely-sized 5 inches (16:9) capable of 16 million colors, this screen offers some seriously vivid visuals. Although it’s not technically speaking HD, it almost (read: almost) rivals the iPhone’s retina display in terms of clarity and vividness-portable video gaming has never been clearer. Everything about the Vita screams high end technology in the palm of your hand; both the front and rear of the console are touch sensitive (both support multi-touch), there are built-in stereo speakers and a microphone (both of pretty solid quality, a big plus for online multiplayer), an A9 core CPU, built-in GPS, Wi-Fi and 3G support, Bluetooth wireless communications, a gyroscope motion sensor and more. Along the lines of tech specs and quantity of features, it has the 3DS beat tenfold.Although most handheld consoles are awkward in some sense to hold, the PlayStation Vita is beautiful to look at and shouldn’t cause much discomfort after several hours of playtime (although because it is a lengthy system, games that utilize both the face buttons and the touch screen-at the same time-can be frustrating and occasionally make for some hand soreness). The face buttons are small but responsive and tightly mounted. Similar to the 3DS, the use of the L and R buttons can be occasionally wonky in games that demand their frequent use; notably fighting games such as PlayStation All-Stars can feel frenetic in their rapid pace on this handheld.There are two models of the PlayStation Vita: Wi-Fi only and 3G-compatible, priced at $249 and $299, respectively. I own the Wi-Fi only model and in all honesty wouldn’t recommend the 3G capability; in an age where 4G is becoming the new standard and most people will already have online connectivity on the go through their smartphones and/or tablets, it’s a bit unrealistic to think most anyone would use this console to surf the web when they’re away from a Wi-Fi connection. Although I can’t speak to any of these factors from personal experience, I’ve come to learn that 3G Vita Internet connectivity not only drains the battery nearly twice as quickly but isn’t all that reliable depending on your location, meaning the reasonably tempting thought of online multiplayer matches while on a long car ride may in reality be plagued by some nasty lag. Additionally, the extra $50 for the console along with the monthly $14.99 payments to AT&T; really aren’t likely to be worth it in the long run for most gamers.One of the Vita’s most excellent assets is its comparatively strong battery life, something several other electronic devices nowadays fail to deliver. As where competitor Nintendo’s 3DS and Wii U GamePad are both bogged down by abysmal battery lives, you can expect to play your Vita for upwards of 5-6 hours before the battery completely depletes (depending of course on what you’re doing), which is very impressive for a handheld console with such high quality graphical capabilities. Like most smartphones, the Vita can quickly be put into standby mode (regardless of what you’re doing onscreen) by simply tapping the power button. This conserves battery even further, so if you only play in spurts throughout the day it can in fact be fairly easy for it to go strong until you’re back home.The console’s interface is clean and user-friendly but does have a few setbacks. Each application appears as a bubble icon which must be tapped to initiate an introductory screen; yet another “start” icon must be tapped a second time to actually open the app. Like Apple’s iOS, apps stay open until they are manually closed (their introductory screen’s page is swiped downward on the touchscreen); the only exception is games, only one of which can be open at a time. While the home screen looks nice and is easy to use, the fact that multiple taps and activations are required to open or close anything can make multitasking a bit frustrating over time, and it seems as though some of these applications overlap and didn’t need to be separate from one another (if you want to start a voice or text chat, view your friends list and check out your friends’ trophies, you’ll have to open three separate applications. A single “Friends” app would’ve really sufficed).Another major success, however, is the console’s mostly seamless interactivity and connection between Vita and PS3. Although this occasionally depends upon different games’ respective capabilities, many PS3 games (and soon to be PS4) are cross-compatible with the Vita, meaning you can start a game on your PS3 and finish it on the Vita or vice-versa. In addition to this, you can log into the exact same PlayStation Network account you use on your PS3 home console to pull up and utilize the same data and information, meaning essentially every digital purchase you make can be transferred/downloaded to your Vita for remote play, and you can also maintain your trophies, ranks and level-ups in fighting and various other games to ensure all your online multiplayer progress is sustained, regardless of which Sony device you’re accessing it from. This cross-connectivity is an incredibly useful feature for avid Sony users, and with the introduction of the PS4, Sony has confirmed that the Vita will have a connectivity to the home console not unlike Nintendo’s GamePad does to the Wii U.As many wonderful features as the Vita does offer, some clunky mistakes were made that may present more glaring issues for some more than others. As previously mentioned, the game’s highest end model is a whopping $300 (plus tax) if purchased brand new; this makes it in most cases the most expensive dedicated gaming console on the market right now (it is pricier than the Nintendo 3DS, Wii U, and even most models of the PS3 and Xbox 360), which is a bit ironic considering its status as a commercially floundering Sony handheld amidst a competitive generation shift. A price drop has been confirmed in the near future, but when exactly this will happen or how much it will drop by is unclear. As of now, the console is honestly overpriced given its stiff competition (in both the gaming and tablet/smartphone markets), so I’d recommend going used if possible (this drops the price by upwards of $60-80+).Arguably the Vita’s most obnoxious setback by far, however, is that this already high price is forcibly spiked even further by the fact that PlayStation Vita consoles do not come with any of their own storage space. What this means is that in order to download or play any games/applications on your Vita at all, you’ll need to purchase an SD card separately along with it (pathetically, ordinary Vitas don’t come prepackaged with one). Worsening this annoyance is the fact that you’ll have to purchase Sony’s Vita-specific micro SD card, because the console isn’t compatible with ordinary ones. The cheapest one is nearly $20, and even this will only net you a measly 4 GB (i.e., don’t plan on downloading more than two or three console games). The console honestly needs at least 14-16 GB for avid gamers, which will set you back yet another whopping $60 for the 16 GB Vita SD card. To put this into perspective, that would bring your total Vita purchase up to nearly $380 after tax. The fact that Sony decided against providing any memory in the console itself was ridiculous; the 3DS may not have much storage space, but at least you don’t have to pay extra for it right off the bat. While there are bundles and starter kits that do in fact come along with the card, you’ll have to be willing to throw down the extra cash (and/or be interested in the games they come with), and most of these only come with the very limiting 4 GB.Regardless of these assets and setbacks, the number one thing on the average gamer’s mind for a console are the games. As of right now, the Vita is plagued by a comparatively sparse software catalogue; while there are Uncharted and Assassin’s Creed for shooters, Rayman Origins for platforming and games like PlayStation All-Stars, Marvel VS. Capcom and Street Fighter X Tekken for brawlers, there still isn’t a great deal to choose from overall and chances are the catalogue of Vita exclusives will have to expand before it’ll be anywhere near a must-have. Gravity Rush and Persona 4 Golden present some of the more unique and enticing entries exclusive to the system, but the near future feels barren along the lines of new releases or IPs. I’d recommend looking into the catalogue of available games and what you’d realistically play before making the purchase.All in all, very much like the Wii U, the PlayStation Vita is a console brimming with features and potential, the latter of which has yet to be fully realized. This doesn’t stop it from being a beautiful system with loads of fun and sleek, addictive functionalities to offer, but it does prevent it from being the fantastic must-have it could be…at least for now. At this moment in time, it caters primarily to a niche audience willing to throw down a fairly hearty amount of cash for decent amounts of hardcore gaming and fun on the go. If Sony really wants to give it the edge up on the competition, expanding the catalogue of software and dropping the price should be the number one focus. If this is executed properly, the Vita could indeed fulfill Sony’s promise as the Vita being the perfect companion to its home console.

reviewText: This game is difficult to review because it looks and feels like an FPS but it's really an adventure game in a first-person view. As you might expect, due to contributions from key player in Half-Life 2, this game feels and plays just like HL2, which in my opinion was one of the greatest games ever created. The environments and maps are beautifully crafted. The voice acting is superb. The RPG elements of upgradeable skills and weapons are awesome. The freedom to approach the game and play it using your style of choice - amazing. All in all, this is definitely one of the most polished and most entertaining games I have played in a long time.The only complaint I have, which is very minor, is that the game wants you to play a certain style - stealth - but the AI is extremely difficult to predict. At times they can spot you from far away, but other times they walk 3 feet in front of you right past you and they don't see you.All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed this game and highly recommend it!

I am so happy in my decision to purchase a PlayStation 4 at launch!  Sure, there was always that small chance I'd get a broken unit like some people sadly did, but I knew if that happened I could get it replaced so I wasn't extremely worried about it.  However, I have been playing my PlayStation 4 a lot since I got it at launch (5 days ago as of this review) and it has been working just fine.All around this system runs circles around the PlayStation 3.  I had a PlayStation 3 for years prior to this and it was a decent system, plenty of good games for it and good graphics for it's generation, but I was honestly frustrated with it a lot because of it's lagging and slow load times, and games often froze up on me...especially bigger ones like Fallout and Skyrim.  I have not experienced a single one of those problems with PlayStation 4 thus far.  It still takes a few minutes for game data to load and install & whatnot, but nowhere near as long as many games on the PlayStation 3 took.There is definitely better frame rate on games for the PS4, and there is definitely a noticeable difference in graphics & detail in many of the games.  Some of the best examples out of what I have played are Killzone Shadow Fall and Battlefield 4.  Even Knack is very clear and looks wonderful.  I downloaded the indie title Flower and its much smoother and noticeably prettier than it's PS3 version too.  Sadly I have not noticed too much of a difference in graphical quality on Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag as opposed to the PS3 version, but it's definitely smoother and runs a bit better.  I look forward to seeing future games on this console, they will no doubt look more and more amazing throughout the systems time span.As far as the home page layout & app services and navigating around, I have no qualms there either.  In fact, I find it much easier to navigate and not as confusing as I found the PS3's to be when I'd first gotten my hands on it.  It took me a moment to realize I had to move upwards to get to the store, profile, and settings icons & whatnot but aside from that I had no trouble.  I didn't need to even glance at the instructions.  My wife was happy with the set up too and created her account on hers.  We've thus far enjoyed playing Knack together, she really likes that one.All around though, this system has met my expectations and I am very happy with it.  In fact, I was so happy with it that I decided to be rid of the aggravations of my PS3 and sold it.  As far as I'm concerned, aside from some of my beloved old school systems to play around on once in a while, the PS4 is all I need.  And I'm not worried about games I'll miss on PS3, because any and all of the ones I enjoyed on PS3 I can download later via Gakai after it drops.If you're contemplating whether or not to get a PS4 or an Xbox One, I'd say go with your gut...I'm pretty equal opportunity geekery.  I actually plan to maybe purchase an Xbox One in time, after a price drop or 2 perhaps.  However, as my first one I recommend the PS4...solid games, quality system, quality media, and great system for the mere $400 you'll pay...as opposed to $500 for an Xbox One because they force you to buy the Kinect which isn't absolutely needed.  It might have been a fairer bet had they done what Sony did and made it an optional buy.  The choice is yours, but I stand firmly behind the PS4 right now.

summary: A definite and obvious upgrade from the PS3
reviewText: So far, I've had a stellar experience with the PS4. Maybe I'm just lucky, but I've had none of the launch issues yet. The graphics are clearly superior to the PS3 in every conceivable way. The user interface is not only much easier to navigate, but it also seamlessly transitions from one page to the next. However, every section can be accessed from the same page, rather than have to scroll through categories like you have to on the PS3. I also very much like the fact that you can simply scroll down on the main page to see what your friends are up to when they are logged onto PSN and you can share your activities as well. Another awesome addition is the ability to post screenshots and gameplay videos directly from the PS4 rather than need a program to do so. This is actually a very cool feature. So far, most of the public features can be tied to Facebook and/or Twitter, adding to the convenience of it all. The DS4 is also a definite upgrade from the DS3, but the specifics of that will be covered in a separate review.The PS4 itself is sleek looking. The product page picture is accurate, but when you actually have it sitting in front of you, it's even more impressive. It's both solidly built and attractive.Eject and power buttons on the console arent completely obvious, as they are touch vs actual buttons, and arent large enough to be very noticeable, but once you know where they are, you realize they are actually better that way as they are unobtrusive and unlikely to be accidentally pressed.So far, the only minor issue I've encountered is with the newest update, which I ended up needing to unplug and then replug it in order to get it to restart and accept the update. However, I had the same issue with my PS3, so it was clearly the update itself and not the system.Anyway, if you are a fan of the Playstation brand, you will definitely love the PS4. A definitely and obvious upgrade from the PS3, as well it should be.

description: To say thatShenmueis an anticipated title is an understatement;  the game made huge waves in Japan upon its release, and American gamers have  been waiting since then to see what the fuss is all about. It's a game in which  the concept itself is the selling point. What if you could portray a young hero  in a fully realized Japanese city? Would you like to participate in and  influence an over-the-top kung fu-style action-mystery flick in your living  room? What if lots of combat, cinematic flourish, detail, and a dash of romance  were thrown in?The game itself is awash in small details, crammed into a confined space. The  city of Yokusuka circa 1986 is rendered beautifully in a short series of  neighborhoods that are long on detail even if short on variety. The story itself  is ripped straight from a chopsocky flick: you portray the young hero Ryo  Hazuki, whose father (a kung fusensei, naturally) is killed before his  very eyes by a mysterious and frightening villain. Ryo must uncover the identity  of the killer and fight his way through the city in an effort to avenge this  wrongful death.Shenmue's Yokusuka might be short on space--in total, it represents maybe  a square mile--but the detail is overwhelming. You can interact with nearly  every person or object that you see; 300 citizens go about their daily routines,  and whom you encounter is as much determined by where you are as when you are  there.Much of this interaction involves combat that ranges fromDragon's Lair-style reaction tests (such as timing a button press to  dodge an oncoming car) to freeform kung fu fighting. Further, each second of  real time equals about a minute of game time, and Ryo has to be home by 11 p.m.  each evening. The game moves at a brisk pace, and each challenge or battle feels  like a race against time. Some might say that gaming doesn't get shallower than  this (you are essentially performing tasks and exploring, instead of gaming),  but the game feels like no other and is ultimately satisfying by the time that  it all ends. In this way,Shenmueis more than a game--it's an event  that's worth experiencing.--Andrew S. BubPros:Compelling, well-told storyGood action and combatFantastic sound and graphicsCons:Plot is familiar to fans of kung fu action filmsTask-and-exploration gameplay might seem slow to action gamers
reviewText: Ever since the launch of the Dreamcast, I've been hearing about a game called Shenmue. I've seen screenshots, first impressions, and previews. When it finally came somewhere around 2000 (hey ! You can't expect me to know all these things !), Sega has proven to RPG fans that it would become the future of RPG's. In Yu Suzuki's latest creation, you will play as main character, Ryo Hazuki in his quest for Revenge for the death of his father. Shenmue is an interactive game that keeps track of the times, changes, and events. For example: if Christmas was only weeks away, someone would be dressed as Santa Claus and some houses and stores would be covered up in Christmas decerations. Okay, that's enough. Now lets talk about how the game is like. First off, the graphics are flawlessly detailed. Some characters don't show much facial expressions, but most of the time, they'll make a slight twitch or an expression even. The sound is...uh...not bad. There's some catchy '80s style tunes (No ! We're not talking about Billy Idol or Aerosmith's music ! It's Sega's customizable '80s music) you'll hear when you go to a bar, somewhere around the outdoors, anywhere ! The voice acting is kinda horrible. Ryo's voice sounds great, but most of them are straight-up annoying ! The more I kept hearing Goro use his squeaky voice, I press the B-button to skip it so I can hear Ryo's. The gameplay and controls are cool. Controling the character isn't really that hard, if you have already played RPG's similar to Shenmue. Some people would complain how slow and unresponsive it is, but it's actually easy (that's what you get for playing to much corny adventure games, kid !). The best part of the gameplay are the QTE battles and the freestyle battles, where you can duke it out with neighborhood gangs and mad locals. The storyline is seamless...until Disc 3. The storyline on Disc's 1 and 2 have great stories, but Disc 3's story lags a bit. Most of the time, you have to race daily, everytime you got to work and after the race is done, you have to do some work as a forklifter. Wow...fun (sarcasm) ! There are times when you'll encounter a fight on Disc 3 (I love beating the tar out of the Mad Angels at the Yokosuka Harbor), which turns Disc 3 slightly exciting. And the most exciting part is, you get to play classic Sega arcade games like Hang On and Space Harrier (100 yen a game). So in the end, Shenmue turns out to be a perfect gaming experience for RPG fans. This game is so great, even some of those ignorant PS2 lovin' Dreamcast haters will give this pup a go. If you want to be taken back to the '80s again, Shenmue won't dissapoint.

summary: A Review at 70 hours in-game (yes, I am ashamed. . . .)
reviewText: I am ashamed because I really don't have that much free time but something about this game just sucks me in and time gets lost. (reminds me of a Vegas casino in that regard). There are countless reviews here and elsewhere that rave about this game, and with good reason.  But so many reviews were up within days of Skyrim's release, and there is no way they could have made much of a dent in the game. So I wanted to give you a review after many hours of gameplay.If you played Oblivion, you have a rough idea of the gameplay.  It is swords, sorcery, or any combination to play in this fantasy world that is a cross between Game of Thrones and The Lord of the Rings. The developers have created a living, breathing world that makes the open world feel of the GTA games feel tight and restricted by comparison.  This world is huge, vast, and seemingly endless.  It is filled with animals, enemies, and flying dragons.  Some knock the graphics a bit, but I think they look pretty nice.  Yes, it is a console port, but most AAA games are now a days because that is where the market and the money is.To say this game is filled with content is to say a beach has a lot of sand.  Content is an understatement - I have no idea how they can pack so many different environments and unique dungeons into a single game.  It is a technological feat to be sure.  You can play this game easily without ever playing Obivion - there is no backstory you need to be familiar with.  The combat is fun and satisfying.  I prefer a sword and shield because the timing of blocking and sword strikes is quite satisfying.  You can walk into any of the major cities and pick up quest after quest.  There are different groups (Companions, Mages, etc.) who all have their own questlines.  I played one quest that became a murder mystery then turned into a completely different quest.  It was long, detailed, and fantastic - and it was just a side quest!You can play this game any way you want - you can wander and stumble into cool stuff, or follow the main quest.  I have invested maybe 90 minutes in the main quest, and the remaining hours of my total 70 hours (the game tracks your time in the game and displays it when you log in) is just playing all the random content and guild quests.  I had never played a game like this until I played Oblivion, which led me to this fine game. The combat is all first person (or you can play in third person if you prefer) but it is real time - no paused dice rolls like RPG's of the past.  Purists don't like that, but I am a FPS guy mainly so it works best for me.I figure there is at least another 50 hours of game play left for me, based on the areas of the world map in-game I haven't even explored yet.  If you have't picked this game up yet, I encourage you to so so.  You certainly get your money's worth.  $50 is movies and popcorn for two for 90 minutes.  Here it gets you 100 plus hours of entertainment.  I would also recommend the Skyrim Game Guide (sold here by Prima) to help you get the most out of the game.  There is  alot to know and many things about smithing and armor and enchanting I never would have figured out on my own.  A guide isn't a cheat, but it helps you get the most out of your game.  It's the same as a travel guide for a vacation destination - you don't want to miss the good stuff once you are there.Good luck and happy gaming.

description: Join Yuna in mission-based, non-linear gameplay, as she and her companions travel across Spira in this epic Final Fantasy adventure.
reviewText: It's official, FFX2 has renewed my faith in sequels. I said it myself...you just can't make a sequel to an FF game. Boy was I wrong. First, FFX was an RPG. Now, take that, put it in a bowl and mix it with some Grand Theft Auto. Now sprinkle a small bit of Tomb Raider on top and then you can pour in one drip of Devil May Cry. Stir, and then put in hours of hard work and development. It gets it's RPG elements from...well...I mean seriously it's FF folks. The Grand Theft Auto comes from the ability to walk up to Buddy and take a mission, some are even optional. It get's it's Tomb Raider from the exploration and ability to jump in some places. It gets it's Devil May Cry from Yuna's shooting and the gunner's gauntlet. Overall, you don't get Devil Theft Yuna Raider, you get FFX2..a solid title that no one that was possible. It is worth every bit of your money, I swear you'll love it!

description: Metroid Prime: Hunters challenges your skills as you control Samus Aran, the space bounty hunter made famous in the Metroid series. A ferocious race, now extinct, has left behind relics of their once powerful warrior culture. Now bounty hunters from across the galaxy are racing against each other in order to lay claim to these relics hoping to harness their power for themselves. It's the race of a lifetime, as you guide Samus to the relics before other hunters can reach them - and use them on her.
reviewText: Metroid Prime Hunters. I've been waiting. I got my DS in January of '05 and I got a "First Hunt" demo that came with it. I can say that I wasn't impressed simply because there was no depth, but I knew that the game certainly could be a great one. Metroid Prime for the Gamecube, to me, was not a very good game. Hard-to-use controls, single player only, a lot of backtracking... and so on. This game has backtracking, but it has easy controls and great multiplayer. Here is my review:PROs: Great singleplayer and multiplayer, best DS graphics ever, little lag suprisingly, cool characters, WiFi, stat counting... so on.CONs: Have to unlock the hunters ( not too hard, just play single player ) , occasional lag, grainy sound sometimes, repetitious adventure mode.Graphics: 10/10. Byfar the best graphics ever shoved into a DS game. They are unbelievable. It's pretty amazing that the whole game was packed into this, let alone the great looking graphics. Very, very nice.Sound: 9.5/10. Very good on surround sound. The only real problem for sound (for me) is that it's grainy; but it could be my DS. You hear footsteps, the creature's noises... everything works nicely.Control: 9/10. Good controls, but it could be some quick corpal tunnel syndrome. I play with the stylus and my hands kind of get cramped up using this tiny little DS. It's not too bad, but I sometimes have to take breaks.Fun: 9.5/10. Excellent WiFi, great graphics, and basically the Halo of handhelds, this game has everything any FPS fan would want. Even though the adventure mode is tedious, the multiplayer is great and anyone can hop in and have a great time with this game. Hell, if you have no one to play with, practice with bots. This game is the best on the DS, and I have no intentions of putting this game down any time soon; and I don't think you will either once you pick it up. Go buy MPH now. NOW NOW NOW!!Here are some hints on how to get through the game:If you're on a long fall to the ground, jump right before you're about to hit the ground; no health lost.To get all the hunters, play single player and get 22% through the game. ( I believe. ) You will have 50% of the Octaliths by this time as well.Special attacks:Samus: Guided missleKanden: Electric balls; dissorient enemyTrace: Invisability + SniperNoxus: FreezeSpire: Ball of fire grenade launcherWeavel: Grenade-Launcher like green bombSylux: Electrical weaponI.M.O, the best Hunters in order:1.) Noxus2.) Kanden3.) Spire4.) Trace5.) Weavel6.) Samus7.) Sylux

summary: Another excellent, and exclusive, title for the DS
reviewText: When Nintendo first unveiled the DS, Metroid Prime: Hunters was one of the first gmaes that were shown to the public.  Well, after some time in development, it's finally here, and much like many other Nintendo games that get delayed, it was worth the wait.  Once again playing as bounty hunter Samus Aran, Metroid Prime: Hunters shows just what the DS can do with the first person shooter.  Anyone familiar with the Metroid Prime games on the Gamecube will feel right at home here, despite the fact that there is no auto aiming feature, and the stylus and touch screen must be used to aim while using the directional pad to manuver yourself.  This allows for some very tight and precise controls, but beware that this will take some getting used to, and this will be a bit difficult to pick up at first.  However, after spending some time with it, you'll find some truly fantastic gameplay.  And this gameplay is truly something to behold thanks to the game's multiplayer capabilities.  Taking advantage of the DS' Wi-Fi capabilities, the game allows for tons of multiplayer options that really show off what the DS can do, and that in itself is a welcome feature.  The game looks slick enough for a DS title despite a few graphical glitches, and the overall feel of the game is pure Metroid all the way.  If there's any low points of Metroid Prime: Hunters, it's that the level design is a bit repetitive, but that's only a minor gripe.  All in all, Metroid Prime: Hunters is another excellent, first party title that solidifies the fact the DS is the best handheld system on the market right now, and hopefully more developers will take cues from this game when bringing first person shooters to the wonderous thing that is called the DS.

reviewText: This game was a little easier than I thought it was going to be. You just follow the clues or hints on the map and do your tasks as an assassin. Escaping seemed too easy though. You can run 3 feet away behind a wall or bench, on a roof, or between people, and you're free... The battles are not hard from what I've seen so far. summary: Good but can be a little frustrating for a 7 year old
reviewText: My 7 year old loves animals so we thought this would be a fun game to get for our next Kinect game.Graphics are well done, the animation of the animals is quite good considering it's just a game.As others have mentioned, the flying narrator is annoying, and even my 7 year old after just about three or four minutes asked "Will he ever go away?"navigation for some of the selction screens is done by swiping a hand in either direction, like erasing a chalk board.  That moves the options to the next one.  Very intuitive for a grown up, not so much for a youngster.The games and tricks are pretty well done - the animals face when it does "play dead" is a riot.  But while the Kinect has done a great job for other games for sensing movement and such, it's not quite so accurate for this game.  "Lay down" has you crouch and pat the floor in front of you, and it seems the system has a real problem sensing this.  And throwing things, while the narrator keeps telling you to throw underhand because it works the best, my son found it works better (we really have found no "best" for this action yet) if he does more of a shovel pass type movement from his chest, and just pushes his hand forward.The animals come at you with various toys they want to play with, and you get the option of playing or telling them "no" and picking your own toy.The opening sequence is so cloyingly sweet that it's almost nauseating, the animals are just a bit too humanesque in their behavior.  But the kid loved it, and that's what it's all about after all...There are options for voice command for the tricks as well, which don't work THAT great, but seem to offer some better luck than some of the gestures.  But there are gestures that work fine, like hands to the sides, jumping, spinning, those are seen and acted on pretty much every time.Definitely has a novelty value here in our house, and my son will enjoy playing this for a while, so even with the shortcomings, it was a good pick.

reviewText: This game sucks.  I played Forza 3 on the 360 and that was a much better game.  I had hoped this would outshine Forza because I sold my 360 and kept the PS3.  I was let down by this game for a few reasons.Good:Good graphics, cars and tracks.Lots of cars, decent amount of tracks.Dynamics of the cars seem right on.Bad:The music is horrible and you CANNOT play your own music, that sucks for a game that requires you to spend HOUR AFTER HOUR racing and listening to its soundtrack. Some upgrades are pointless and offer non realistic gains.  Customizing the handling is also very lacking.Visuals while racing.  In Forza 3 you could spin the camera 360 degrees around at any point while driving and in the garage/paint/shop, you could look at your car every which way, in GT5, nothing! except front and interrior! But still is a great game, not so straight forwad, and really challenging, it has given me a lot of time to think and enjoy of it.

summary: One of the best games of the year
reviewText: Anyone can pick up this game and play - it is so simple and addicting. Some people might be turned off by the fact that it is so easy, but that's what makes the game so great for me and other casual gamers. Even if you're not a huge Star Wars fan, this game is still a lot of fun. I even enjoyed watching the cut scenes because they're so funny. I ended up also buying the game on my PSP because I knew I'd be more motivated to play through and unlock everything in the game if I could play it on the go.If there was anything that I would complain about, it's the fact that the extras aren't all that exciting, at least not unless you're a hard-core Star Wars fan. I was thinking you would get to build all these vehicles with legos when you collected all the mini-kits, but all you get to do is look at the finished version of the vehicle outside the cantina, which acts as a hub to all the levels in the game. Once you pass all the levels, you're basically just collecting as many studs as you can to unlock all the characters and cheats.Fortunately, the levels are fun enough that I don't mind playing through many of them multiple times. As I said before, I bought the game on a second system, so I've played through many levels  4 or 5 times now and it's still a lot of fun.

I won't go so far as to say that ARKHAM ASYLUM was one of the greatest games of all time; I haven't played a whole lot of games, so I can't really make that judgment call.  I can say that it was one of the greatest games I've ever played, and was a breathtaking experience, the video game equivalent of a cinematic masterpiece.  Beautiful imagery, in-depth storyline, plenty of action and intrigue, and incredible acting.ARKHAM CITY ups the ante.  If anything, it's even more breathtaking.  Sure, a lot of the set-ups are clearly ripped from the previous game (the interior designs of a lot of places look almost identical), but that's really not an issue.  And yes, it has some of the same game-play problems (when fighting, you often lose track of your opponents); but again, big deal.  You can live with it.What CITY brings to the gaming experience is a fully-immersing superhero game.  You become Batman, as he glides through Arkham City, the new super-penitentiary for Gotham's worst criminals (and what a brilliant idea THAT was, giving the worst of the worst free reign over such a large chunk of territory).  There's something going down in Arkham, and Batman must figure out what it is.  It involves Hugo Strange...and an apparently-sick Joker...and the lives of a whole lot of people...CITY has quite a bit to offer.  Unlike with ASYLUM, here we have fully-fledged side missions; you can take them at your leisure (and they can be rather difficult).  You unlock more stuff by doing them, so I suggest you hop to it.  You can also play as Catwoman, again on side-missions (sort of like deleted scenes).  In many ways, she's more entertaining to control than the Bat, as she can crawl up buildings and across certain ceilings.  Along with these (and more) new features, CITY brings back many of the things we liked: the gadgets, the perfect voice cast (Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy, anyone?), the fast-paced swooping action, the blow-by-blow street fighting...I don't get excited about too many games.  ARKHAM CITY has me excited.  Simply put, it's fun to be the Batman.  Especially in a story as rich and layered as this one.  To me, the greatest games are all about the depth of the story; if I'm going to play for hours on end, I need something to keep me glued to my controller.  ARKHAM CITY has that something.  It's a breathtaking experience.  Yes, almost like your favorite movie--except this time, you're a part of it.

I should start by saying that Return to Castle Wolfenstein is one of my favorites. I found Wolfenstein to be just about exactly what I expect from a shooter these days. I found the game play to be very entertaining and original. It had a engaging story and a very unique concept with the Veil capabilities. The AI was acceptable and the graphics were good (its no Black Ops, but that is ok). AND the game offered something you rarely see anymore -- the chance to carry more than a couple of weapons. The game is so fun and when you kick a contender ass it will get you satisfied.This is a good choice and the controls are so accurate, all you need to do is check the illumination of the room for the head tracking to work as it's supposed to but it has the option to turn head tracking off as well. summary: Words can't describe how good this game is.
reviewText: I'm in my 30's and remember vividly going to the arcades to play MK1, then MK2.  Talk about a blast, with 20 people putting their quarters on the machine to get in line to play, everyone stoked about the game, crowding around, getting into it.  God those were good times.  Those may never be brought back due to everyone playing from their households now, but let me tell you, this MK is BEYOND anything I could have hoped for.  The line-up of characters is perfect, the attention to detail in the graphics is unreal as you can see in the stage backgrounds, Krypt, fatalities, etc.  And if you wanted brutal, this game is EASILY the most extreme and gory MK so far.  There is a TON of single player content to go through with story modes, challenge tower, regular old school fight ladder with specific endings for each character like the old days, etc etc etc.  The fighting engine is pretty fast paced and I'm working on getting used to that, it is definitely much deeper than old MK games with the power bar and options you have with that.  Literally every special move comes in two forms due to the power bar and they all affect the opponent differently so there is endless combo options.  Tag team is kick ass and easy to learn also.Seriously, this is a game for the ages.  DO NOT PASS THIS ONE UP.

reviewText: First off, let me be clear that the game content in Skyrim is fantastic. The scenery is epic and the quests are enjoyable. The open-ended world with so many opportunities represents the greatest of what powerful computing systems can do. Unfortunately one must be careful with such complex machines; attempting to carelessly port a game from one system to another can lead to an unplayable game.Bethesda made various mistakes with the PlayStation 3 release of Skyrim. They didn't offer reviewers the chance to play it before release, and the reason why soon became apparent. The game featured frame rate dips, huge save files, interminable load times, and freezes that required reboots. Patches were slow and sometime made the issues worse. The company repeatedly blamed Sony for designing an inferior console, refusing to take responsibility for the issues and ignoring the fact that other companies have been quite successfully developing for the console.Downloadable content has yet to be released for the PS3 and Bethesda has delayed development thereof until they release the latest package. Still no timeline on when PS3 owners can expect new content.You would hope that after raking in so many millions of dollars, Bethesda would start to care a bit about their loyal fans on the PlayStation 3. Evidently nothing has changed. We will be the last in line for fixes and content additions. This makes my advice rather succinct. Do not buy Skyrim for the PlayStation 3.Update: The water problem can be fixed; see comment below.

description: Combining the best parts of role playing games and first-person action games, Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines plunges players into the dark and gritty vampire underworld of modern day L.A. as a recently embraced fledgling vampire in the service of the city's dark Prince.
summary: How come this didn't get more attention?
reviewText: This game is completely awesome. Just like it's prequel "Vampire: The Masquerade - Redemption". I may be biased because i love RPGs, but this is just the way a game should be. It has that GTA-style of gameplay. Walking around the city in 3rd person using "WASD" (or 1st if you like by pressing "z") and taking on different assignments. And after a while you'll realize that this is not only a great RPG, this is also a terrific 1st person shooter. That vampire-element just makes it so much cooler than other games, creating a great underground atmosphere. Highly recommended.*****

reviewText: Treyarch took a great game like Spiderman 2 and made it even better with Spiderman 3.This game has a lot that spiderman 2 didn't like:1)Swimming Thats right you can swim in the lakes and rivers and also the sewers.2)Subways and Sewers in freeroam This is a major improvement over Spiderman 2 which didn't even have these in freeroam.This is part of the much bigger city that this game contains.3)Better Random Crimes There is more of a variety you still have muggings,gang fights,and road rage missions but there is more variety and even with the missions you have to chase cars you don't bang on the car anymore you punch the guys hanging out of the window then you either stop the car by opening the trunk and distroying or webbing up the engine or tearing the doors off.4)A bigger city overall Not only are the subways and sewers accesible but the city is far larger.Example Spiderman 2 had only 1 bridge Spiderman 3 has 6 however only 1 goes out to an island.Note:The ps2/wii has only 1 bridge but that version is very different from 360/ps3.5)Graphics Spiderman looks better then he ever has before when playing on next gen as do buildings and other surroundings.There is also a lot more traffic and more detail in the people.As good as the graphics looked on spiderman 2 they look antimated compared to these.Sp 3 graphics look much more relistic.6)Buildings are higher.The Empire State Building for example is higher then it is in Spidey 2.7)Some Buildings are enterable in freeroam once you beat the story.8)Skydiving There are several skydiving missions from several buildings one of which is the Empire State Building.These are fun and they show the beauty of the city when dropping from such high altitudes.Why you skydive there is an opera song with some unknown singer.It's appropiate for the skydive.The skydive missions are really pretty at night.9)Bomb Tours Some of the story missions have it were you have to dismantle bombs but you can also do it in freeroam if you want to.These are fun challenges.10)Gang fight challenges.At anytime when you get ready you can go clean up gangs and see how fast you can do it for rewards by pulling up the map and going to challenges.There are 3 gangs The Apokilipse,Candy Aresonic(Sexy Girl Gang)and The Dragontails(These are the toughest gang to fight.)There are 10 missions in all and the bosses you fight are Calos The Madbomber Lizard,Scorpion,Rhino,Kingpin and Kraven as well as the movie villins Sandman,Venom and New Goblin.You also have the gang bosses which there are 3.In freeroam there is so much to do like random crimes,daily bugle missions etc.At some point in the game you aquire the black suit which is great.It features some moves that do more damage and the swinging is faster as well as the jumping.You eventually lose the black suit toward the end of the story but once you finish the game you get to play all the way thru again in the black suit.You also still have the red suit.You switch between the 2 in the characters menu.You have a second save point once beating the game.Also the Ps3 version will let you dowload the New Goblin.It's only 5.99 but he is fun to play around with in free roam and he can go higher then spiderman.He can actually go way over the highest buildings.Spiderman 3 has also added photomissions some of which you will do in the Daily Bugle and Dewolfe missions but also in the Lizard 1 and one of the Candy Aresonic Missions.Bruce Campell is still doing the narration and training.Subway and Sewer LocationsThese are hard to find when you first buy this game because they are not on the map.However you learn were they are by looking at buildings on the map close to the location.First off The Conners Lab Sewer.This is the only sewer in freeroam but you can get to it from 2 locations.The first way is to go to the Garment District on the map.You will see a short fat building.There is a subway entrance behind it.Go down the subway and to the left.Take the stairs on the right down.Once in the train station turn right.Swing until you see a large hole in the wall on the Left side.Go in the hole and go all the way to the end and you see a manhole.You will be prompted to mash keys on your controller.Once you open it go down.You will see another hole go down it.Adjust your camera and run to the end of the platform.You can then jump off into the sewer and start swimming.If you swing or swim far enough you will come to the end and see 2 holes in the wall above.These lead to Conners Lab which you can enter.This sewer only features small waterfalls as opposed to the big sewer at Morningside Drive were the Lizard 2 and Conners 2 mission is which feature tha large waterfalls.Unfortuanly the Morningside Sewer is only available in storymode.Now from the Lincoln Subway the Conners sewer is on the Right side of the wall instead of the Left.The right side is where you'll find the hole in the wall at Lincoln but it goes to the same sewer.Grand Cental Station SubwayThis building is located between the Empire State Building and Christler Building and there is a tall building behind it.This is the only building that has a subway in it.The other subways are in the street.Look for the short wide building on the map with a tall one behind it.Grand Central is white.There is a door you enter.Go to every door till you find the one that opens.Garment District SubwayOn the map the short fat building.The subway is behind it.Lincoln SubwayOn the map you will see a short fat building behind Central City Park.Behind the building is the subway.Lennox SubwayBehind and to the West of the Thoubourough Bridge.If you can't find it go on the bridge and come back down it looking to the left.You will see a building meeting the end of the bridge.Look straight left and you will see the subway.Harlom SubwayYou will see these buildings with green roofs.In front of the first one there is a subway at the street intersection.City Hall SubwayYou will see a industrial park with buildings in the grass.On the left side out from the grass there is a subway.There are more but that's all I'll list.Once you know where to look on the map their easy to get to.If you can't find them you can always get to them from the Grand Central Station Subway.The subway itself is done well you can even enter the mens and womens restroom.Some of the womens restrooms have tokens in them.There are also tokens hidden in other parts of the subway.There are trains that run thru it as well as abandoned subways.Notes of interestThe balloon,hospital,saving men from falling and rescuing people from a sinking boat are not in this game.You also can't catch a helicopter to gt to Liberty Island like you could with Spidey 2.Once you beat the game twice you can't start another game unless you create a new profile.Once you start a new profile you can switch between your 2 profiles and play your saved black or red spidey or the new game on your other profile.There is no need to delete your saves.The Cineractives are cool and once you get the bosses health down you do a cinematic which makes it look like your really watching the movie.They can be stressful thou because if you don't nail them you have to start over and if your health is low it you will die and have to start the whole mission over.After beating the game go into the menu and the arenas section.There are several differnt locations you fight in.Something I'd like to see in the next game are the Morning Side sewer in freeroam where you can open the manhole.An even bigger city with Coney Island and also a way to get to Liberty Island and the other 2 in this game.Also I was hoping to play as Venom in this game but you don't get to play as him.I hope this will be corrected in Spiderman 4.I hope Sega will look at Spiderman 3 and do The Incredible Hulk game like this one.Imagine the Hulk being able to swim and go into subways and sewers.I recommend this game as well as Spiderman 2.
